awd_abstract_narration:
The DNA of multicellular organisms is packaged into linear chromosomes. The goal of this project is to understand how cells deal with DNA breaks, specifically how breaks near the ends of linear chromosomes are treated differently from breaks in other locations. The outcomes will help clarify why breaks near the ends of chromosomes do not trigger a DNA damage response while those at other locations do, and how this differential treatment maintains genome integrity. The project will offer research training and career development opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and a post-doctoral scientist, particularly aimed at increasing diversity in the STEM workforce. Results from the project will also be integrated into coursework in order to teach students current concepts of genomic stability.

A fundamental question in the field of chromosome biology is why telomeres, the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes, are stable while internal double-strand breaks are not. DNA double-strand breaks promote genomic instability by DNA recombination and cause growth arrest by activating cell cycle checkpoints, but telomeres are stable and allow continuous cell growth. Telomeres are composed of DNA repeat tracts bound by specific proteins that "cap" the chromosome end to prevent its degradation and block checkpoint activation. This project will investigate how telomeres accomplish these functions by using an inducible telomere formation system that leverages powerful molecular genetics tools in the Schizosaccharomyces pombe model system. The specific hypothesis to be tested is whether S. pombe telomeres recruit effectors that post-translationally modify checkpoint proteins to block DNA damage signaling. Known candidate proteins will be tested and new candidate proteins will be sought by proteomic approaches in a comprehensive approach to identify the effectors of DNA damage checkpoint suppression at telomeres. The project will offer research training for graduate and undergraduate students, and a post-doctoral scientist, and project outcomes will be integrated into coursework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW:

The goal of this project is to investigate how telomeres, the physical ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes, block the DNA damage response and cell cycle checkpoints. We previously showed that the current model of checkpoint suppression is not correct, indicating that an unknown mechanism blocks checkpoint activation. We have developed a telomere formation system to leverage the powerful molecular genetics in the yeast model system Schizosaccharomyces pombe, and have shown that telomere formation suppresses the checkpoint response. We hypothesize that S. pombe telomeres recruit effectors that post-translationally modify checkpoint proteins to block DNA damage signaling. We tested known candidates and developed methods to identify new proteins in work to be performed by a postdoctoral fellow and undergraduates as part of a systematic training plan.

intellectual merit: 

Telomeres are the ends of chromosomes, and how the stable telomere ends are distinguished from the unstable ends generated by double-strand breaks at internal chromatin is a fundamental question in the fields of genome integrity and chromosome biology.  Double-strand breaks (DSBs) are sensed by a “checkpoint” machinery that halts cell growth, so cells have a chance to repair this damage.  DSBs thus cause growth arrest, and also promote genomic instability by DNA recombination.  In contrast, telomeres have functions that allow continuous cell growth and complete replication of the chromosome end.  Telomeres are composed of DNA repeat tracts bound by specific proteins that “cap” the chromosome end to prevent its degradation and allow its complete replication by standard DNA synthesis and telomerase. Damaged telomeres that lack some telomere proteins do not activate the checkpoint that senses DNA damage, indicating that a subset of telomere proteins play a role in checkpoint suppression. Our lab made the first inducible telomere formation system in S. pombe, where an induced DSB exposes telomere repeats to form a telomere. While the side of the induced DSB with no telomere sequences is degraded just like an internal DSB, an internal DSB activates the DNA damage checkpoint to cause the cell cycle to pause while the forming telomere does not. Therefore, telomeres show an “anti-checkpoint” activity that can span the DSB to prevent the cell cycle pause. These activities are conserved in organisms that diverged from S. pombe almost 1 billion years ago, indicating an important general mechanism. We hypothesize that telomeres recruit an activity that post-translationally modifies the surrounding chromatin and DNA damage proteins to disrupt checkpoint signaling. Our exciting results from this funding period were that we discovered a new function for a telomere protein in distinguishing telomeres from DSBs.  The protein works by restraining the nuclease activity of another protein involved in DNA replication. We also identified a new gene that is required for the new, short telomere to avoid activating cell cycle checkpoints while it is being elongated. Our future work will investigate the mechanism(s) by which this protein may act.  Finally, we constructed and tested a system that will allow us to identify proteins recruited to the new telomere or a new DSB for purification and identification using a technique called proximity labeling and followed by mass spectrometry. We showed that the conditions required for proximity labeling still allow telomere formation, setting the stage for exciting future work into the mechanisms of checkpoint regulation.  Our results establish a paradigm for an evolutionarily conserved process that can be extended to other eukaryotes for how cells distinguish short telomeres from DSBs.

Broader impacts: 

This project had a significant educational impact on the graduate student, postdoctoral fellow and undergraduates who participated. The postdocs followed a specific plan involving training for lab work, presenting their data and mentoring others. Previous trainees left the lab for science-related positions, indicating that this approach is successful. We trained several undergraduate and high school students in this project, which introduced to real-life applications of their STEM studies.  One of these undergraduates has moved on to graduate school in biology. The undergraduate training also provided mentoring opportunities for the postdoctoral fellows in the laboratory, which both enhanced their grasp of the subjects they taught and provided them with valuable experience to use in their future careers. During this project, the PI joined new diversity, equity and inclusion programs at our institution that recruit under-represented minorities in the STEM workforce from high schools and colleges in Northeast Ohio.
